Well, I just LOVE LOVE LOVE this movie! It has great elements, and interesting yet off-the-wall characters. And it's very special since it was Vincent Price's last film before his death in 1993.Other than the Grandmother Winona thing, it was a good movie. But the snow thing was really unnecessary...PLUS it didn't make very much sense. The movie still would have been great if not better without that little part.

reviews.review_title: Edward Scissorhands: a unique master piece
reviews.content: First of all, I have to say that although I am not such a big fan of Tim Burton's work I enjoy watching his movies. Edward Scissorhands is not the exception and I must say that this film is quite a master piece and I consider it to be his finest creation. The movie tells the story of an artificial man named Edward (the legendary Johnny Depp), an unfinished creation, who has scissors for hands. Edward is taken in by a suburban family and falls in love with their teenage daughter Kim, who's magnificently interpreted by Winona Ryder. Burton shows the audience an imaginary world that is so odd that it entices them in a very peculiar way. People in this place might seem weird or eccentric but they are just a clear reflection of our society. Through a very original and moving love tale, Tim explains us that scissorhands can be harmful but not as harmful as human hands. I totally recommend this solid well told story which is a unique critic of all the bad and ugly aspects of society, such as gossip, lies, violence, selfishness, prejudice, religion, etc.9 out of ten.

Go watch this movie again. Then go rent the 1958 French film Mon Oncle by Tati. Now tell me this isn't the exact same film. They are. There are obvious differences but too many parallels to ignore. Both films are great. It's startling how alike they are though. Both involve a bizarre outsider in an even more bizarre modern world. Some scenes in Edward Scissorhands are almost copied from Mon Oncle. I don't say this as a knock on Scissorhands, I just think it's either an amazing coincidence or Tim Burton definitely looked at Mon Oncle for inspiration. Either that or I'm crazy, which I have considered.

My sister bawls everytime we watch it. It is sad. *SPOILERS* In short : Boy/robot comes out of mountain,falls in love,people are mean to him,chase him back up mountain. He has to live alone after he fell in love. The girl he loved is sad & remembers him as an old lady. Edward creating ice-sculptures is also the reason why it snows. GREAT MOVIE! I loved the music,cast,setting,acting,it was a 10!!!!! WOOH!

Anyway, This is a wonderful movie. Before I saw it I had slew of people hounding me about how it was too "Out There" or "Weird" I, however, am the queen of Out There, so it was no surprise just how much I liked it. It was full of those scenes that just make you wanna go "Awwwww" as well as those that make you wanna say, "What the Hell? Get away from him, he deserves better than you!"  It did make me think, however, just how much further they could've/Should've gone with it. **Spoiler**After all, I think we all would've had a much bigger warm fuzzy after the credits if we would have gotten to see Edward and Kim with some kids or something instead of finding out he outlived the rest of his days locked up in that castle doing whatever it is he does in his spare time other than making art and snow. **End Spoiler**Overall, If you like sweet, Warm your heart, Want-To-Mess-With-The-Ending, Forrest Gump sort of movies, then this is your place. Or if your one of those Johnny Depp fangirls...In which case...have fun. (by the way...Johnny Depp is the same age as Garth Brooks, I hope that threw a couple of you guys off track)

This is the very first movie in which I saw Johnny Depp - and I was hooked.A lot of things were very unbelievable, such as how the heck does the man dress himself with those hands? But then, it's a fantasy, or maybe I should say sci-fi story. The topiary forms were most unbelievable, as those animals, etc. couldn't have been shaped from the trees and bushes that he worked on. The viewer just has to go with the flow and not be too critical of those things and must allow for a great stretch of the imagination.That said, I love Depp's acting and since this movie, I have bought everything of his that I can get my hands on.

I'd seen a clip of this film as a child and since seeing it I had been absolutely terrified of this movie. I've refused to watch it for close to 15 years. That changed today. And I have to say this is one of the most gorgeous films I have ever seen. The story is so poignant and beautifully told that I was in tears most of the time watching it. Edward is so innocent and gentle that you can't possibly be afraid of him. I actually saw alot of myself in him. And by the end I'd completely fallen in love with the film. There are very few films that can be described as perfect. But this is one of them.

reviews.review_title: short thoughts, and some cute scenes!
reviews.content: Okay, first here is my collection of short thoughts of this movie.I thought it was so unique how they gave Edward scissors instead of human hands. I also thought it was lovely how Edward was so quiet, but he didn't need to talk to share his thoughts. He was a quiet guy, but had many facial expressions and SOMETIMES he said a sentence or two. But that was rare.Cute scenes time!Cute scene # 1: When Kim says "I Love You" to Edward and they hug! It was sooo cute! (Kim was the teenage girl's name, right? I dunno.) Cute scene # 2: When that lady was trying to make out with him in that store place, he got freaked out and ran away. The lady chased after him and she was like, 'EDWARD?!?! Come back this instant!' That was classic. Cute scene # 3: When Kim came home and started to get undressed in her bedroom, she saw that Edward is laying there and starts screaming! But then it's cute because later in the movie Edward develops a crush on her. Cute scene # 4: When Edward gives haircuts!! I want a haircut from Edward!So that's my review, any questions?

This movie originally made in 1990 is another staple in Tim Burton's timeline of enjoyable, fun, and environmentally original pieces of work. Though the story is bogged down by cliche conflicts and sometimes annoying plot devices this movie is still a great work of art and a prime example on how Burton's style flows though a movie. But Burton's style though bright and fun sometimes lacks on the story side of the coin. Characters seems sometimes come off flat and have unclear motives. The movie focuses on one neighborhood and how the residents come to see and accept this very different person into their lives. This is an interesting idea for a movie but it not totally original or done well in some areas.
 
Overall, Burton's sometimes boiled down, cliche story can bring down the movie but his patented Burton style still helps it rise it above others in its genre. A joyful ride with good performances all around.

Tim Burton has updated an old tale of the misunderstood and scary-looking beast (Edward) and his love relationship with an incomparable beauty (Kim or Winona Ryder).  The tale is modernized (sort of) into a suburbia America setting with 60's styles houses, clothing, cars, and people.  The reason this movie is so likable is simply because it interweave's romanticism and darkness with bits of comedy to relieve the tension of the viewer.  This dark fable puts chills down your spine (e.g. when Edward first steps out of the darkness of the attic to meet Peg) while at the same time fills your heart with an equal mixture of happiness and sorrow.  In addition, Burton's  picture was filmed with great elegance.  Who can forget the scene when Edward is carving the ice sculptor and Kim is dancing in the snow he has created?  The ending of the movie is not as melancholy as everyone believes.  It is revelatory about who the real monster is.  This movie can obviously be compared with other tales of individuals who were also outcasts in their society such as Frankenstein and Burton's other masterpiece, Batman.  This work of Burton's is his personal statement to all pariahs who have ever been spurned by the greater populus.

reviews.review_title: a true classic movie,with great direction and great acting
reviews.content: i watched this movie when i was 8 and recently watched it again and my thoughts about the movie came more than true.it is a fascinating piece of art put to a motion picture very touching and well performed.it is a wonder that the movie was not even nominated for the major oscars.this movie deserved to be in IMDb top 250 as it is one of the most finely crafted movies i have ever seen. faultless on 10recommended strongly if you have a good taste in movies

reviews.review_title: An unsuccessful attempt to parallel a classic.....
reviews.content: Edward Scissorhands, desperately trying to imitate the classic movie, Frankenstien, failed completely to capture the emotion and brilliancy displayed by the previous classic. Why someone would want to parallel such a classic like Frankenstein is beyond me. The acting was poor in some places and the characters were very much clichéd. Although, Johnny Debt did portray Edward pretty decently, for it was such a bad part to have, being that Edward was pretty much confused the entire time. I also thought the themes in this movie are overused. I know already that society is unwilling to change and is shadowed by corruption. I didn't need a poorly created movie, being more shallow/unconvincing than creative, to enlighten me on this subject.
What a great film! Wonderful writing, directing & acting. One of the best films of the '90s. Thank you, Johnny Depp & Tim Burton!

reviews.review_title: Hard as rock, sharp as scissors, soft as paper - 'Edward Scissorhands'
reviews.content: Being director Tim Burton's picture 'edward Scissorhands' combines a sense of dreamy storytelling with great special effects.  The film tells the story of edward, a young, mysterious man with a different appearance but a kind human heart.Edward lives alone in the town's notorious 'house on top of the hill' until the day an Avon lady calls and takes him home to live with her in their town...unfortunately not realising the potential consequences.As always the director (Sleepy Hollow, Beetlejuice, Batman) works visual magic and with a top screenplay by Caroline Thompson the film captivates with a slight twist on good and evil.  With spectacular sets, Tim Burton, uses a fantastic, surreal mixture of dark, haunting sets and bright planned 60's streets.  These sets are stunningly visual and vibrant colours play off each other and contrast to edward's dark yet beautiful home)Starring a then trapped TV drama heart-throb, Johnny Depp (edward) gives a performance of a lifetime without really having to speak.  His heart-warming performance enables you to sympathise with this character and his habits, such as extravagant topiary and makes you also sympathise with how difficult people are to get on with in life.  Johnny Depp is among a fine cast including Winona Ryder, Diane Wiest and Vincent Price as the inventor.The other characters, mainly the family and the neighbours start to annoy you with their precise lives but soon it becomes apparent that this is the danger for the harmless edward.  As in a lot of Tim Burton films the characters are obviously greatly worked into and can sometimes seem a derivate on stereotypes or to the extreme.  Whatever your view, this works in 'edward Scissorhands' and adds to the tragedy that affects anyone who isn't 'normal'.Some people may find the start a little slow but that does not hinder the fascination throughout the film and I find this also shows the quick descent into sad chaos as the characters begin to realise the consequences of trying to change things. `Sometimes you just can't change things.' The film doesn't really have a set time period because with love it doesn't matter.The story is original and gently funny, with a slight touch of danger. This film, to me, also represents the narrow mindedness of our societies and touches upon the notion of racism and discrimination and the sad consequences of the extremes of this.  It is shown through the family's neighbour's reception to edward.  Above all though the film is about true love and works under the children's question 'where does snow come from?' - The film answers the question, you will have to see it to find out.For me 'edward Scissorhands' is the best visual journey ever told.  With make-up from Stan Winston and music by Danny Elfman, the whole film takes you into a spectacular surreal world.  'edward Scissorhands' is an incredible love story, visually a treat and one that will remain in your heart forever.Star rating - five out of five

Tim Burton strikes again in this beautiful fairy tale about Edward, a man with scissors for hands. This is the second Tim Burton movie I've seen, and this one is just as good as the other one. He is great at showing the emotions of the characters in this film. It'll go from funny to sad to another emotion so smoothly. Johnny Depp is great at this character. He brings the sweetness to Edward. He also shows how hard it is for Edward to survive with scissor hands.Again, good facial emotion. Winona Rider was good at showing the change in feelings she feels towards Edward. Danny Elfman also brings the perfect musical score to set the mood. The only thing I did not like about the movie was the pastel colors of the town. They were ugly!! But, all in all, go see this movie. It brings out the person in you that has always wanted to fit in a certain way but couldn't.

*****May be spoilers ...... *****Okay, I've seen this movie like a million times and I can't help but think about how I would do things differently if I were in Peg's situation. Here's what:  I would keep this poor creature inside my house all the time and not allow my nosy annoying neighbors to gawk at or exploit him!  If he never goes anywhere unsupervised, chances are he would not get into trouble. Boy, that Peg was pretty naive.I give this movie 8/10 simply because I get so irritated at the characters' poor decisions concerning our Edward.  Ending was also waaaaaay too violent for what could have been such a charming, fanciful movie with a happier ending!  Not that I didn't like that Edward stood up to Jerkface, but still... a bit too much I would say.

Edward Scissorhands is an emotional and often hysterical fable that captures our need to feel accepted and loved by the society we live in.The plot depicts Edward, a creation who, with scissors in the place of hands, is isolated from the town of Suburbia, until a kind and generous Avon lady befriends him and welcomes into their neighbourhood and home. However as Edward's time in the town continues, his individuality creates both triumph and tragedy for him and his new family.The acting in Edward Scissorhands is superb. Without much dialogue, Johnny Depp provides a career-defining performance as honest and vulnerable outsider trying to belong, while Vincent Price, Dianne Wiest and Kathy Baker offer tremendous support. The romance between Edward and Kim (a slightly disappointing Winona Ryder) is extremely genuine, powerful and appreciated by varying members of society.This leads to the powerful and beautifully created ending is one that is tear-inducing yet heart-warming.The final piece to the perfect and poignant puzzle is the complex art that is the direction of genius Tim Burton, and his vision that is carefully portrayed in the chilling score, attractive set and realistic screenplay of this one-of-a-kind feature.Sad one moment and hysterical the next, Edward Scissorhands is an emotional, colourful and enjoyable storybook-like film that pleases it's audience over and over again.

EDWARD SCISSORHANDS (Tim Burton) **** out of ***** (Contains maybe minor spoilers))One thing is for sure, this movie introduced me to the world of storytelling and movies in general at a young age.This is the first movie that I vividly remember seeing for the first time, some 10 years ago now I think. It HAS been 10 years ago since I've seen this movie. We taped it from television, and I watched it, I watched it, I watched it, until suddenly, the tape just disappeared. A very disappointing day in my life if you will :). 'Edwards Scissorhands' buried itself in to my memory as the most fascinating film I've ever seen.And now, some 10 years later, now that I'm attending film school, I had the chance to order it on DVD. You can imagine how happy and thrilled I was when got it in my hands. All the memories of the movie returned to me in an instant. I felt like a little kid for a second. This movie has been haunting me for all that time, 10 years without seeing it again, it was almost too much to bare.And what I expected, this movie hasn't dated one tiny bit (maybe for the first long shot of the town and the hill, where you clearly see that the hill is animated). I still consider this as one of both Burton's and Depp's best, without a doubt!The innocence that Edward radiates throughout the movie is just wonderful, you feel for him. If he feels fear (for example the scene where he is locked in Jim's house), you also can feel it, if he feels mad, you can understand why he feels mad. It's just amazing how Burton created such a fantastic character. It is a Burton says: 'Edward Scissorhands is about wanting to communicate, but not being able to'. I think this is the reason why I can connect to him. Like everybody else, I've been in such situations.
Visually, this is among the most breathtaking pieces of cinema that I know. Especially the mansion scenes with Edward and The Inventor create a rare feeling. And don't ask me what I think about the ending scenes, it's sad, sad, sad. Very hard to keep your tears to yourself. Beautiful scenery. Just see it for yourself, you will know what I'm talking about.Danny Elfman, the genius behind the theme music. I thank him for giving this movie that extra dimension that it needed. The music in 'Edward Scissorhands' keeps hauting you until you get amnesia, I will promise you that. Just brilliant...The is movie combines comedy, romance, drama, fantasy and so much more. It just all blends together in one fantastic film.Thank you Tim Burton and Johnny Depp for creating this.

reviews.review_title: Arguably the greatest original screen-story ever
reviews.content: "Edward Scissorhands" is a story about innocence and a parable about good and evil. Johnny Depp plays an inventor's unfinished creation - Edward in this ferociously original film. It tells the story about when Edward comes out of the isolation of his inventor's house and mingles with human society. It is essentially a human story about an outsider with Gothic overtones. Depp's performance is a sheer and moving character study of innocence-cum-alienation. I was moved to tears towards the end. The best Burton-Depp collaboration till date. It has every potential to be a cult classic. Don't miss it whatever you do. You shall come out a better person.

Its my favourite film, everyone in it were at their best, Johnny Depp, Vincent Price and Winona Ryder. It made my cry at the end where they never saw each other again. Johnny Depp was great his child-like voice and the way he walked moving his scissors as he did. The first half of the film its like a children's film, everyone has different coloured houses and their cars match their houses but the second half it gets darker with all the people turning on Edward and then were they chase him away for doing nothing wrong, the opposite in fact saving the boy from being run over but the people think hes trying to hurt him and then Edward killing Kim's ex boyfriend, Jim. Vincent Price is the inventor who doesn't finish Edward before he dies in one of his last roles before his death from lung cancer. The director, Tim Burton who is well known for his odd main character that the audience loves anyway, Edward Scissorhands and Ed Wood, both played by Johnny Depp, in fact Burton used Depp again in Sleepy Hollow. All of which are great movies but never made it big at the box office, the only Depp film that has is Pirates of the Caribbean but none of his films are bad he is in Platoon, Nightmare of Elm Street, Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood, Sleppy Hollow, From Hell, Ninth Gate etc all which have cult following.

reviews.review_title: Unforgettable story of a man with scissors for hands who is exposed for the first time to a colourful town who don't welcome him warmly.
reviews.content: Edward Scissorhands is brilliant, although probably only this attractive to those who have enjoyed other Burton movies. Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder are both made for their parts and although the story isn't incredibly believably (it's not really supposed to be) the colourful neighbourhood where it is set is a comforting atmosphere for the audience. This is definitely a film to see. It's a magical experience with original ideas and the notorious imagination from Burton is once again no let down to his fans. Edward is an unforgettable character. This is a one-of-a-kind experience. If you enjoyed this film, check out 'The Nightmare before Christmas,' as it's also quite enchanting.

this film is my all time favourite every time i watch it it puts a lump in my throat. It is so touching just the way that Edward (Johnny Depp) acts and how lonely he is i would recommend you see this film i almost cried at the end when she told him she loved him and that was all he needed to hear oh by the way Johnny Depp is brilliant in it. Also the music is great it really makes you feel sad it goes very well with what is happening in the film. Johnny Depp is great he really gets to know his character he really is a great actor. you should definitely see this film!

What is there to say about Edward Scissorhands, besides that is the best movie to have ever graced the face of this earth? It is my favorite movie of all time, mad by my favorite director Tim Burton, starring my favorite actor Johnny Depp, and composed by my favorite composer Danny Elfman. These three men, plus the rest of the cast have created a truly magnificent classic that everyone should be required to see. I simply cannot put its brilliance into words. I most definitely suggest you should see it. It's the poingant story about a man with scissors for hands and his first encounters with the real world. It's a beautiful movie that has touched a countless number of hearts and inspired a countless number of souls. Thank-you Tim Burton. You are amazing.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest movies I've ever seen...

reviews.review_title: An amazing piece of work with a beautiful outcome
reviews.content: Tim Burton is definitely one of my favourite directors, his films never seem to fail in my mind, as he is such an amazing director. He always chooses the darker and more Gothic approach in film making. His film Edward Scissor Hands is incredible. With excellent acting from Johnny Depp, he looks so sweet and innocent, and yet he is mistaken by the Surburbia society to be evil. When a lady decided to take him in, and fix his scars, she doesn't quite realise what she's got herself into. The young man Edward is not any 'normal' person, he was created by an inventor who happens to be Vincent Price. Edward has scissors for hands and causes more damage than immediately thought. Also starring in the film is Winona Ryder, who is rather annoying as she seems to be loved by Edward, she is not the best actress in this film, but i think Johnny Depp is excellent and he makes up for her bad acting. Directed superbly with amazing music that will make your heart beat faster and slower at the same time.Highly recommended for film fans every where, this is an excellent film and should not be forgotten.
I love how Edward is smiling and everything ells is Total Tim Burton things Till The music Till the design

reviews.review_title: I tear up everytime I watch!
reviews.content: Edward Scissorhands is a movie that defies explaination.  It is part Frankenstein, part Phantom of the Opera, and ALL Tim Burton.  Burton can use the dark and bizzare and transform it into the epitome of what is beautiful, natural, and pure e.  Depp is beyond words in this movie...literally.  Depp has a handful of lines yet he speaks pages with his expressions and body movements.  Diane Wiest is the perfect Avon lady while Alan Arkin is deadpan for the 60-ish suburban husband.  Winona Ryder is actually the weakest aspect of the movie...but I still love ya Winona! (you kick in The Crucible!)   Danny Elfman's score alone brings tears to your eyes.  His use of the child-like voices in Edward's Love Theme sends chills.  The ending is not a happy one, but I think the non-Hollywood-formula ending gives this movie its originality.  Check this one out...or better yet, buy it!

reviews.review_title: Beautifully unique movie portraying contemporary issues
reviews.content: I love this movie through and through for many reasons.  Like most of the people who have commented on this film, I also think it was casted perfectly and it was pretty cool.  It's characteristic of most Tim Burton films.  Once again, he places the picture with contrasts between dark and light.  But it's always a contradiction.  In this film, the townspeople wear bright, loving colors yet turn out to be black and shrivelled at heart.  On the other hand, Edward comes off as a scary, unknown stranger at the beginning and really is a person with the biggest heart of them all.  Everybody loves the new person at the beginning but that love turns to hatred at the lack of understanding the people have for Edward's condition.  Behind the action and thrills of the ending, Burton tried to get across a lot of issues that plague our world today.  One is prejudice.  People at first are intrigued by the mysterious man with scissors as hands.  But as time goes by and Edward makes a few slips of judgement, the townspeople start to become scared of Edward and even start to despise him and the people who took him in.  It's also a wonderful love story between Ryder's character and Edward.  She's the exact opposite of the townspeople in that she dislikes Edward at the beginning but begins to understand his problems and even falls in love with him.  This may be a metaphor to interracial relationships in America.  It's a rather sad story with moral ethics laced throughout it.  All and all I think every American should see this movie.  It's entertaining and meaningful. ********** stars

The Edward sadness make us understand the stupid habits of the ordinary people. He likes the beauty, he is innocence, he wants to be loved. His scissors make him rejected for the rest of the people even dangerous. He don't understand the interest behavior of this strange local community. He want to be loved but this is very difficult when you loved someone in silence and you have scissors for hands. In this Masterpiece you can find magic, poetry, marvelous characters that remind us the story tales that we loved and still appreciate. ...And Vincent Price with a memorable character like the Ed inventor. Superb. Said I that this film it is entirely Poetic?

This film is one of the best I have seen in the nineties. It is beautifully directed and superbly acted. One of the most compelling aspects of the film are it's subtle juxtapositions and the way we get such a superb insight into the world of an "uncommonly gentle man".I love Burton's style and the way he does nothing the way he is supposed to.

reviews.review_title: The most underrated film of all time
reviews.content: Edward Scissorhands came out at a time when Tim Burton was at his best. He had just completed "Batman", and was one of the "most wanted" directors in Hollywood. It comes as no surprise that his next film "Edward Scissorhands" was not a complete success. No director has ever made a career without making one or two misfired films. With Steven Speilberg you have "1941", with Alfred Hitchcock you have "Dial M for Murder", and so on.This movie was shunned by critics for its ending. They said it had too much of a "Hollywood Style" to it. Yes, I suppose that's true, but i think the ending works well in this case.I love this movie, its one of my favorites. I highly recomend it to anyone who loves Tim Burton's unique gothic style. It has everything a movie should have in it: good acting, a creative story, and it brings you to another world. This is one of my favorite movies of all time.My rating:10/10

To me this film is one of the most beautiful and touching films i have ever seen,it is one of the ,if not THE best film to be directed by Tim Burton, and the acting from Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder is brilliant. This film is so sweet and lovely it always makes me cry, there's a gorgeous child like innocence, which makes the film so special. I think Johnny Depp deserves all the credit he can get for this performance, the childlike subtle beauty of Edward is a pleasure to watch. Vincent Price does a great job of being the old inventor up in his mansion at the top of the hill - definitely a perfect film to end his career.This film deserves 11 out of 10, to me this is the perfect film, and id definitely say its my favourite.

Beautiful, artistic, moving and a truly unique film. Can compare to the 1990s movie version of Keats, Percy Shelley and especially Mary Shelley. Heart and soul in a truly gothic tale long forgotten. Tim Burtons soul on show for all to see, much like the suburban neighbors and their judgement. The most beautiful film I have ever seen.

Right from the snowy logo of the 20th Century to the end, the film looked unique. Visual brilliance, fantastic cinematography(the cross-section of the city with the painted houses and the scene when Edward cuts the snow sculpture and Kim dancing to the snow are my favourite) and brilliant work by Burton and his best man for any job, Johnny Depp. This film is one for the ages.
I watched this movie as a child with my older sister and it started my love affair for cutting and styling hair.

reviews.review_title: Praise for one of Tim Burton's best.
reviews.content: Director Tim Burton uses his trademark Gothic perspective to bring to life this film. And the result is excellent. Sometimes I don't know which is more terrifying; the dark, unsettling world of Edward or the pink and blue, bland world of conformity he is thrust into. The movie itself is driven by Johnny Depp's powerful presence. You can't help but feel strongly for his title character, wishing that he could move past the impossible: trying to achieve acceptance from a world that he could not understand. Winona Ryder is Edward's love interest, and really this is her only great acting, aside from Girl, Interrupted. This movie will stay in your mind for a long time. 4 1/2 out of 5 stars, not to mention arguably Depp's and Ryder's best performances.

I think "Edward" strikes an emotional chord with so many of us because we recognize our own struggles with adolescence that Edward experiences as he's first introduced to society. Those who've experienced the sometimes-bitter and painful process of growing up in modern America will immediately recognize and empathize with his shy innocence, his awkwardness, his feelings of isolation and "different-ness" and difficulty fitting in. Whose heart doesn't reverberate in sympathy with Edward's first experience with love, and the joy and heartache and rage that it can bring? I think most can recognize his feelings of "incompleteness" - visually represented by his "scissors hands." And, who wouldn't recognize his feelings of (suddenly) being a misunderstood monster, with a beauty inside that seemingly no one else can see, or cares to, and whose own emotional inexperience and clumsiness leads us to have hurt those we love most? When he's told "you can't touch anything without destroying it!" - who hasn't felt that way about themselves? I think that's part of why this film can carry such an emotional punch, as Burton touches on themes of sometimes sweet, and sometimes painful experiences many of us can immediately relate to, because we recognize similar experiences in our own adolescence.Depp's portrayal of Edward is sublime - I find his range of expressiveness - fear, curiosity, puzzlement, joy, love, anger, rage - so eloquent, yet often transmitted only via his eyes. His facial expressions are limited and stoic, partly by make-up, but also, I think, deliberately. Yet he manages to convey a remarkable emotional range - and somehow, he takes me with him.The story arc has been told and re-told here - stripped bare, I admit, it's almost silly in its apparently banal storyline. In fact, when I first heard of the premise of the movie, I thought it sounded ridiculous. Until I saw it.In addition to Depps' performance, Ryder has some beautiful moments here, and Wiest and Arkin are strong throughout. I found the Esmerelda character to be a bit, well, "off" - I'm not sure her role was strictly necessary. But on-balance, the neighbors and the neighborhood are pitch-perfect, at least to me - perhaps this is more about "me" and people of a certain age, but the suburb and its inhabitants as depicted was a stunning recreation of the late 60's/early 70's Southern California suburb where I grew up.The early mood of a modern sweet fairytale diminishes over time, as the events surrounding Edward become more "real", more banal. I assume this was intentional on the part of Burton - but still, the penultimate act of violence is jarring, and I wish Burton found a less brutal way to resolve the conflict. I'm sometimes afraid that some may turn away from the movie at this point, and fail to see the heart-wrenching, and redemptive final scene.Because despite a few flaws, if the final scene doesn't bring tears to your eyes, I don't know what to say. I can barely watch the movie now without almost inexplicable tears.I don't know that this movie is for everyone. But for those who "get it", it's a touching and memorable film.

reviews.review_title: One of my all-time favourites - a contemporary fairy tale
reviews.content: Describing Edward Scissorhands... Where shall I begin? It's only fair to start with the impact it had on me  all those years ago when I first saw it.It's one of the few films that managed to touch me in a very unique and emotional way. I had only seen the promo and trailer on television, when I became mesmerized by the astonishing world and characters Burton created for this film. I knew then I had to see it. And I knew then that I would love it. Because this is no ordinary fairy tale  no, this is real magic.Not only are the parts sublimely castthe music is amazing and so appropriate, the set is delightful and interesting to watch, Edward's innocence and frailty is an instant sympathy factor and the budding love between him and Kim is one of rare kinds  one that I was captivated by, and am still.The film knows slow, funny, romantic and exciting scenes. All of which show us more of Edward and the life with his new 'family' outside of the professor's castle. I began falling more in love with the story and the characters, especially Edward, while watching it. My favourite scenes include the obvious 'snow dancing' scene, the funny show and tell scene and the precious 'hold me  I can't' scene. But, honestly, it's hard to pick a particular scene from a film that is so dear to my heart. How can I put it? It's a story that invites you into a different world. If only for a little while. Still one where good and evil exist, but where a bittersweet happy ending holds victory. Yes, the ending. Also a scene that completely ran away with my heart. I remember fighting my tears during the final scene  especially when I saw it the first time. Of course I knew it was going to end that way, how else could it? And the fact that It did only made a bigger impression on me and made me treasure the film more. It was an honest ending. An "I love you" I will never forget. And one of which I hope there will be more in Hollywood in the years to come. It is impressive what Johnny did in this role. There's no other word for it. Or maybe 'wow'. From that moment on he became my favourite actor. And he still is. And no matter what projects he works on in the future, I doubt that is going to change. So, yes, when it comes down to it; I'm giving this film a 10 out of 10. Simply because I think it's that good. One of my all-time favourites - a contemporary fairy tale

Oh bless, i love this film! Well i do now anyway.When i was little i saw a picture of Edward Scissorhands (not knowing it was Johnny Depp at the time) and i was absolutely petrified. It has to be said, for a younger, he is scary looking!! Now, after over-coming my fears, i have watched it dozens of times and really, really love it. Winona Rider is brilliant, even with that creepy old lady mask at the beginning and end (which is scarier,in my opinion, than a guy with scissors for hands). Johnny Depp still has a strange sort of charisma, it's difficult to explain but you can't help falling in love with him.And at the end when he kills the nasty guy i was ecstatic! i definitely would have shaken his hand...

Tim Burton has proved himself as an amazing visual artist over the years with movies such as the first two batman films, The nightmare before Christmas and beetlejuice. But the film he is mostly remembered for is this towering achievement. It is almost like watching a modern day version of Frankenstein. Johny depp plays the role of the boy with garden shears for hands down to a tee. The dark imagery and haunting soundtrack from Danny Elfman make it all the more worhtwile to see. Although this movie might scare some children (I first saw it when I was 4 and it scared me to death) it is actually a beautiful fairy tale and a tragic love story about two people who are made for each other but their differences tear them apart. All in all I strongly recommend this wonderful gem from the master himself Tim Burton. Its a pity that he doesn't make more films like this today.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the most moving, touching movie ever made!
reviews.content: What can one say about Edward Scissorhands that has not been said a million times before. A true delight from start to finish. This is the movie that turned me on to Johnny Depp and he has never let me down since. This movie could easily have shot Depp into the mega-star/mega-bucks bracket and it is too his credit that he still continues to make the kind of movies that he wants to make and shuns his potential super-star status. I adore this man!!!! I have watched this movie umpteen times but now find that I fast forward certain scenes, and relish others.  I love the scene where Ed is trying to pick up his peas with his scissor blades and also the scene where he is the 'show and tell' at school - perfect timing, perfect imagary.  The ending is deeply moving.  A masterpiece of story telling. Johnny Depp has said that he identified with Edward completely and was deeply sorry when filming ended as he knew he would never again look in the mirror and see his alter-ego looking back. Talented, gifted, misunderstood - Edward or Johnny?  We may have lost Edward Scissorhands but thank God we still have Johnny Depp!!

Provocative and brilliantly shot, "Edward Scissorhands" succeeds on all levels, as both a touching story and a cinematic wonder.  I must be one of the very few people who likes this movie through and through; right behind "Jude", this is my second favorite movie.

Tim Burton has done a wonderful job. It was so sad but really beautiful! It was also really funny in places (when Mrs Monroe kicks her dog I couldn't stop laughing!)
It was so true to life.The suburben life everyone lived was freakily acurate! The way Johnny Depp acted as Edward was so touching. I had never really noticed what a fantastic actor he was.I don't really know what else to say about this movie that no one else has said! If u haven't seen it, go to the video store and rent it NOW!! It is such a good film. It will make u cry though! 10/10.

It's nearing the end of 1999, and this is *still* my favorite Tim Burton film. This is definitely my favorite modern fairy tale. The Elfman score is exquisite, the story is haunting and lovely; the film is simply magnificent.While some have criticized -Edward Scissorhands- for being too "heavy-handed" or too obviously allegorical, I think that the inherent message of the film is one that is universal enough not to be a distraction to the film's beauty. The plot and the characters are too original to evoke feelings of "been there, done that", even while it may be true that everyone has felt alienation at one time or another.The content of this film runs rampant with "Burton-isms", the clever absurdities that are Burton's trademark in films. This film does contain a lot of humor and oddity, but unlike films like  -Beetlejuice -, its story revolves around something that is not alien to anyone - love. This is a love story that breaks the heart. The originality lies in the details, and in the conclusion. It's been a long time since someone has written a fairy tale love story that doesn't end up with the beautiful girl living happily in the castle with the handsome prince. It is the ending that gets me everytime. This is a truly beautiful movie.

After I saw this movie, I couldn't stop thinking about it in the next days. Exelent directing and casting, especially Winona Ryder and Dyane West. I didn't say Depp because he IS the movie, his Edward touches something deep inside you, because we all know what it is like to be misunderstood and hated for it, but Burton reminds us that we do it to others. Just see the film. And try to think about it.

I just watched the DVD version of the movie. Even though it was made in 1990 and even though I watched it in 2006, the age of the Spidermans and Pirates, it still impressed me very very much.The ending was sad but appropriate. The girl mouse shall always be the girl mouse! I liked the fact that Edward didn't try one bit to fit in with the world. He stood out though confused against it. Even in the direst of circumstances did her forget his values. It touched me to see the cruelty of the world crush him in its hellish hands, but just like the silver lining present in every cloud there shall always be a soul mate for each and every one... even though you can't be together forever.Watch it, might seem like a drag in the first half but I'm sure you'll come out smiling although sad at heart. 10/10 for Johnny Depp and his superb acting. 8/10 for Tim Burton and the movie.

reviews.review_title: Must-see, then see again and again.
reviews.content: The description of this film as a "contemporary fairy tale" may be off-putting to some, as this is a genre which many movie enthusiasts tend to avoid.Thus, the movie had been released for some years before I felt inclined to watch it. I can tell you, it was only a few days before I watched it again and, there is little doubt, it is more satisfactory the more you see it.I, quite quickly, realised the error of my ways and I resolved, not to pre-judge any movie, on the grounds of its perceived genre, at any rate.This is an enchanting cinematic experience. It engages the viewer, firstly with the charm of the characters and plot, also with the stunning visuals throughout and, ultimately, with the message, subtlely conveyed, that non-conformity to recognised norms (however fickle), should not necessarily exclude either individuals or groups, from equality, in our fad and fashion conscious society.I will not detail the plot. Suffice to say that Tim Burton caricatures so many of the main players and suburbia itself, highly effectively, without their losing their charm and appeal.Dianne Wiest represents everyone's mother. Warm, soft, brimming over with love, the ultimate humanist. Alan Arkin, everyone's dad. Stoical, hard-working, well-intentioned, patient, tries so hard to be a good parent.Winona Ryder plays the sweet, beautiful teenager who, despite her initial misgivings, finds the horrifically-incomplete Edward somehow entering her heart, in a meaningful way, thereby rendering her relationship with Jim (Anthony Michael Hall), irrelevant and base.Jim is subsequently seen for a moral bankrupt and his spite ensures there will be no happy ending to this fairy tale. Mayhem ensues.There are serious issues raised, some of them addressed, in this film. That is, after all, what cinema is all about (or is it?).Our social norms and mores are challenged as the naive Edward is taught the rights and wrongs of daily living in this, or any, suburb in the western world.The destructive, iconoclastic quality which undoubtedly exists in our species, is reflected in the crowd, aroused by blood-lust, baying for that of our hero. One thinks of that hillside, two thousand years ago.Burton manages brilliantly, to retain the important strands of the message, while charming the audience with the purity and beauty of the film and its characters. Who can forget that scene where Kim (Winona Ryder) dances, hands upward, with the uninhibited joy of a child seeing snow for the first time.The overall package is emotionally, intellectually and aesthetically pleasing. I recommend it, without any reservation. Don't miss out on this movie because of narrow prejudices you may have. Don't be like me.
