A small town like a paradise, the uniform overall color scheme is different, but you can also see the similar qualities of ordinary people; Edward in black tight leather armor can not be wrapped in a relaxed coat after all; he is simple and kind. , Should not understand that the friendly heart of the world is even sharper and sinister than his own scissors; he can only return to his own paradise, living in black and white monotonously; in the end, only the heroine can appear in his heart like snowflakes Light and pure happiness.

It is only in a Tim Burton world that such a scenario could begin a film...we have a dark, gothic looking castle sitting in the midst of small-town America. It is unlike any other home in the town, and it clearly is a place to be avoided. It exudes darkness and isolation. Yet, in a Tim Burton world nothing is untouchable and no place is unreachable. So, we become witness to the town's ever present Avon Lady (Dianne Wiest) walking dutifully to the door, knocking on the door and meeting its sole inhabitant, Edward (Johnny Depp).Wiest is, perhaps, the perfect actress to play this role as she herself presents as eccentric yet strangely maternal. She listens to Edward unlike anyone probably ever has, and she learns that he was created in a laboratory, however, before he could be finished his creator (Vincent Price) died leaving him with scissors for hands.She becomes the protector of Edward and takes him home to her family, a spouse (Alan Arkin) and daughter (Winona Ryder). Much of the first half of the film involves Edward's transition to a more socialized existence, and the natural curiosity of the neighbors, ranging from a nosy Joyce (Cathy Baker) to a wide range of others. In many ways, Edwards becomes accepted for his gifts with his hands, especially for lawn decoration. His scenes with Winona Ryder are quite tender, and scenes with neighborhood children of great innocence.Yet,being in small-town America always exacts a price. Edward becomes the object of ridicule and hatred of Jim, a town bully (Anthony Michael Hall).Here is where the script from Burton and Caroline Thompson begins to do a slow fade into mediocrity. Where the first 2/3 of the film had been unique, innovative, touching and imaginative, the latter 1/3 of the film becomes stereotypical Hollywood and the ending itself feels largely plastered on and created only for marketing purposes. It is, in my opinion, where the film loses its potential for greatness.As with nearly all Burton films, "Edward Scissorhands" is beautiful to behold with stunning cinematography, art design, costume design and production values. Burton always has a stunning vision and the ability to create that vision within the context of film. Yet, "Edward Scissorhands" also reveals Burton's willingness to occasionally dip into his barrel of cliche's in order to finish a story. Furthermore, he occasionally rests on the style of his film instead of using that style to enhance the development of his characters. Thus, towards the end when we are forced to deal with Edward's conflicts it is difficult to become emotionally involved in the scenario.Johnny Depp is simply marvelous in the role of Edward. Long a courageous actor, Depp inhabits a character that by all accounts should have been a freak or caricature. Instead, Depp gives Edward a soulfulness and depth that makes you ache for him until the final third of the film."Edward Scissorhands" is a special film. It's a unique, lovely and enchanting Burton vision brought to life beautifully. Bordering on masterpiece, but nearly sabotaged by the final third of the film, "Edward Scissorhands" will move you even when the script fails him. In a time when too many films fall into the cookie cutter studio formulas, "Edward Scissorhands" is a reminder of the power of a unique story and a grand vision to entertain and inspire.

After seeing a tiny part of Edward Scissorhands on TV a long time ago and hearing that it was only "strange" I didn't think much of it. After seeing it completely and understanding it better, I have to say it's one of my favorites. It's very funny and also incredibly sad from the haunting music in the beginning to the very last well acted scene.It's a mature and dark story told in a fairy-tale like way. It takes a simple idea really (a young, secluded, shy man with scissors for hands thrown into regulatory society) and depicts as many emotions, jokes and scenarios from hilarious to bitterly sad as possible. What would a man with scissor hands be good at? The movie is unique and strange and that's part of what makes it great; its a look at reality from an odd angle. The fact is; there are people like Edward out there (I'm not talking about the scissorhands obviously) and there are, sadly, neighborhoods like that out there. There are too many good morals to the story to put down here.The entire cast is perfect for their roles. The directing is brilliant as well as the music. One of Time Burton's best (if not best). This movie solidifies for me what a great actor Johnny Depp is. Winona Ryder & the small part of Vincent Price is just another reason this is one of my favorites. A true masterpiece, an instant classic that is perhaps very under-appreciated or misunderstood. A must see for a true movie fan.

I think this is definitely Tim Burton's most amazing film-every aspect seems to fit and all the acting is excellent. The best part, I think, is the simplicity. The film communicates about being different and how people are not accepted, a basic moral but done well, Tim Burton-style.The film showcases the director's unique abilities with his own interesting characters and little details-and the score by Danny Elfman is really memorable. Johnny Depp will forever be remembered for not just Jack Sparrow, but for Edward Scissorhands, the role that brought him into film. His character is a sort of Of Mice and Men idea, hurting the things that he loves. Winona Ryder and all the other supporting actors play their roles to perfection, notably Vincent Price in his last film role.Although the suburban design is a bit outrageous (the blandness idea is really forced onto you), it really shows a place we find boring may be an amazing place to others.The film is an astonishing combination of music and visual effects and I think it may well be Tim Burton's greatest film.

In recent memory, there have been films and books borrowing heavily from older, classic, and revered horror novels. Many fail in their attempt. This movie is one of the few that borrow from these older tales, and end up creating something just a good and unique in its own right. This movie can't exactly be called dark, as it contains very bright colors and a cheery atmosphere. This movie is beyond that, the perfect neighborhood where the story takes place is so cloyingly 60's it becomes ironic. A bland palette of cut and paste houses and perfect yards adds to the atmosphere of the overall film. This is one of several aesthetic choices like the sharp contrast between this neighborhood and the massive castle ominously situated above it,makes this movie a piece of visual art to go with this story. The story is similar to classics like Dracula or Frankenstein in some way, but develops a distinct stamp of its own throughout the film. The mob of villagers is replaced with nosy gossipy women and the evil vampire is gone, with simply a tortured, unfortunate, and innocent soul in its place. There is humor in this film, but the farther you go in the less it happens. This darkness builds up until the climax, which explodes in a burst of irony and utter desperation. Only one spark grows in the midst of this bleakness. The villagers er, neighbors at first embrace Edward but lies and ignorance cause them to immediately label him a monster. The spark I mentioned is the one who began by fearing and almost despising him, I'm of course talking about the closest to a love interest this movie has. If you haven't watched yet I can't perfectly explain this relationship, I can only stress its importance to this film. The film cuts off well, leaving no hope for a sequel, as is proper, and leaving you with an odd feeling of sadness, joy, and utter.. well I can't properly describe this last emotion. No matter how hard I try I can't properly describe this movie, to understand you must see it. It contains a magic of its own distinct from any other movie. The last bit of review I have left is one acting. The stand out performance is definitely Johnny Depp as Edward Scissorhands, he barely talks throughout the movie but the body language perfectly shapes and emotes the character of Edward Scissorhands. This is his finest role in a slew of many. The rest of the acting is well done as well, with some hilarious bits from the nosy neighborhood women. This movie is the perfect modern horror classic, which only makes sense if you've watched the film. If you've never seen the movie before I utterly recommend it, if you've seen it before watch it again. You may see something more in the film. If you dislike the movie I respect your opinion, but utterly disagree.

*POTENTIAL SPOILER?*
This film really is magical - from the elaborate old Gothic mansion sets to the beautiful score - you really feel like you are in another world or a fairytale.Director Tim Burton brings us the tale of a man who was created by an old inventor who died before he could be finished. This has left him with scissors for hands - hence the title "Edward Scissorhands".An Avon lady from the surrounding area finds Edward and brings him home. This is his story.....Johnny Depp plays Edward to perfection. Almost all of his performance is delivered through his eyes - they show the wonder and terror at the new people he meets and the strange surroundings he finds himself in, and they especially show us his feelings for Kim (the daughter of the Avon lady) whom, from the first time he sees her picture, he falls in love with. His longing for her is made all the more painful at the end when misunderstandings and ignorance inevitably lead to tradegy.....All the supporting players are excellent, the characters all have traits that we can recognize and identify with - even if they make us uncomfortable (see: Kim's boyfriend).I really would recommend this film to anyone, it's almost flawless. And of course it's educational too - now I know where snow comes from.....

This tenth anniversary edition is sure to be a superb addition to any DVD collection. All of Tim Burton's films are worth looking at, but the fairytale qualities and heartfelt emotion in this film make it close to his best, second only to "Ed Wood". A simple fable of a boy, Edward (Johnny Depp) whose inventor (Vincent Price, in a beautiful finale to his career) dies before completing him, leaving Edward with scissors for hands. Edward lives alone in the inventor's gothic mansion until Avon comes calling, and he is taken in my Dianne Weist's hilarious Avon lady. In surburbia, Edward finds love (Winona Ryder as the ultimate fairytale princess) as well as prejudice - Tim Burton is always making films about outsiders who just don't fit into society. The performances are great - Depp is a revelation - the production design and cinematography are breathtaking, and Danny Elfman's best ever score envelopes and enriches the entire film. Outstanding

reviews.review_title: Tim Burton fans should watch it! (Even if they aren't into romantic movies.)
reviews.content: I'm going to say this: I'm not a giant fan of the romance genre. It's either cliched or boring. There are some exceptions like Disney films, Grease, Fault in Our Stars, Shape of Water, and this film. This is one of my favorite Tim Burton movies next to Beetlejuice! The performances are amazing, the music is spine-chilling, and the movie, as a whole, just feels magical! I cannot think of a single flaw that this movie has. This is a tearjerker film that every movie fan should experience at least once in their life.

reviews.review_title: Beautifully directed, wonderfully enacted by Johnny Depp
reviews.content: As a big fan of Johnny Depp, I just had to watch this movie. In a nutshell, this movie depicts how an 'artificially created' person, with scissors in place of hands is suddenly brought into a suburban society and how he struggles hard, maybe too hard to be accepted. While at first he gains popularity through his fairy tale like artistic cutting creations and innocent and pleasing personality, the hypocrisies of the real world start taking it's toll; to the point that his deeds of trying to help people with the purest intentions are misunderstood and more often than not deemed threatening. Johnny Depp puts in an out of the world performance as Edward. Right from his facial expressions of an artificial man portraying innocence, confusion, love and child like excitement (when he sees the suburbs for the first time) to his body language portraying nervousness, wholehearted indulgence (while creating his works of art) and the frustration of being a misfit,it is just a treat to watch him enact this simple yet complex character.The movie has created a number of emotionally captivating scenes; ranging from how Edward first senses Kim's feelings towards him but realizes that very moment that he does not fit into her world to the scene where Edward is presented with a pair of real hands by his creator but in a moment of misfortune loses it before he could even use it.The music score provided by Elfman just adds extra magic to the emotionally rich scenes throughout the movie.One of the best movies that I have watched in recent times. Watch it if you haven't already.

I loved Edward Scissorhands. I laughed, I cried, I wanted to kill people who were mean to Edward. The entire movie had a fairy-tale feel to it, and Johnny Depp was perfectly cast as the main character. I loved his little pouty confused face. The film follows his plight through love, loss, and being different. Throughout all he remains kind and innocent, but in the end it becomes clear that Edward was too good for the world.Winona Ryder played the teenage daughter of the family that takes Edward in well, but Johnny definitely steals the show. I love Tim Burton's writing and directing. I give it a 9/10

This movie is I think the first one, which really filled me with awe when I was young. And also the one which made me interested in movies in general. I have watched it today after at least eight years. And still, it touches me purely.The storyline under Tim Burton's direction and visual perfectionism just goes absolutely well with Danny Elfman's magical music. This combination can't really leave you unaffected. I cannot give it anything else that ten out of ten. Maybe it is only my affection, but I just love it.If you haven't seen it, do it right away this evening..:)

reviews.review_title: A Beautifully Arranged and Emotional Film
reviews.content: One of my all time favorite movies, Tim Burton directs another one of his outstanding pieces. There's a marvelous cast playing imaginative characters, especially Johnny Depp, who in the movie plays Edward, and says only a few lines, but was still best for the part and really gets you close to him while watching the movie. Along with Danny Elfman's beautiful score, the plot is well written with touching scenes that that are really meaningful. And there are of course a few funny scenes that can really crack you up. And most of them are quite simple too. This movie truly shows how powerful movies can be. I swear, this is one of the most emotional films I have ever experienced watching, and it got me crying for quite a while in the end of the film.I sincerely do recommend this film to anyone who has a big heart, is a fan of Tim Burton, enjoy's a good cry, or would like to see what love can truly be. This isn't one of those romantic chick flicks such as "The Notebook" or the "Titanic" that makes you cry. This is an incredible film that is much more beyond that, and that will remain in you mind for a long long time.

This is a truly heart-breaking film, which will leave even the toughest person with tears in their eyes. The compositions by Danny Elfman which accompany the main feature, are truly amazing.Although this film doesn't have the special effects that we are so accustomed to enjoying in recent movies, this film benefits from not being overloaded with complicated plots, intricate characters or hours of fight sequences.Basically, this is the touching story of Edward, an abandoned and incomplete experiment. Left with scissors for hands and unable to touch anything without destroying it, Edward is brought out of his secluded world into the busy hubbub of daily life. Forced to live amongst humans for the first time Edward must learn to survive in a prejudiced society, which offers no allowance for his needs. However there are a select few, who see Edward for what he is inside, rather than for the blades he carries.I cannot recommend this film highly enough. This film is for anyone and everyone. With charming characters and a thrilling plot, Edward Scissorhands is one of my all time favourite films. I have heard several critics comment that this film "drags on"... I couldn't disagree more, but there is a noticeable acceleration of pace in the last 20 minutes of the film. However, don't just take my word for it - watch it and find out for yourselves.

Tim Burton is defined by a very particular aesthetic, characterized by a gothic and lugubrious atmosphere which is however extremely poetic and touching. 'Edward...' is one of the best examples of this. This movie touches with an exquisite refinement topics like the impossible love, the incomprehension of the society in front the people different and the loneliness. Definitely good.

Edward Scissorhands is one of my all-time favorite movies.  People tend to complain that its light, happy, feel good atmosphere (conveyed beautifully) is destroyed at the end with murder and unpleasantness.  All of this is true,  but its not a flaw.  I think that the drastic atmospheric change in the end is exactly what Tim Burton had in mind.   The general message of the movie (to me at least) is that society can corrupt the most innocent of souls, this message comes across loud and clear.  Edward Scissorhands, however, is also a beautiful love story (fine, they don't end up together in the end...did Romeo and Juliet end up together in the end?).  The end of the movie always makes me cry.

reviews.review_title: One of the most touching movies ever
reviews.content: In my opinion i think this is one of historys most touching and moving movie to date. Its an excellent story about Edward Scissorhands and how us people is happy and greedy when it is for our benefit, but when its not how we just put blaim to the innocents. But the movie is also about the power of true love, that can't break anything. Much to learn here, even thou the movie has its logical misses. But it is still stand out as great romantic movie. Depp is fantastic and Winona is beautiful and with Burton behind the camera, it's all perfect.

this movie is one of my faves!!! everything about it is so cool!The cast is very well chosen- Johnny Depp was definitely the right actor! I don't think Tom Cruise would have made Edward everything that Depp did, even though Cruise is also a talented actor! Winona Ryder was well suited for Kim- sweet gal!Tim Burton made an excellent movie & has shown beauty in a very original way. All his movies i have seen are very different to others and all are ... what do u call it... exceptional...:)

I just saw this movie for the 4th time and it got me again. Such a wonderful movie, with Johnny Depp in one of his best roles. He, Tim Burton (Director) and Danny Elfman (Music) make this movie unforgettable. And of course, Winona Ryder plays a great role. Summary **Minor Spoilers**An Inventor tries to turn a machine into a man, but dies before he can finish it. When a saleswoman knocks on the door where the Inventor lived, nobody answers. She walks into the house and finds the unfinished man, who has scissors instead of hands. The saleswoman takes the man, known as Edward, to her house and then an wonderful adventure begins...Depp definitely deserved an Oscar for his role as Edward Scissorhands.My Rating: 10/10

Edward Scissorhands is and will always be the best movie that ever existed. Tim Burton's fantastic mind has created a completely breathtaking universe and story. Johnny Depp is perfect for this role and so is Winona Ryder. This movie is so beautiful, I can never see it without crying.

One of the best movies of all time! The casting, the performances, the frames, the dialogue, the style it is truly a masterpiece. Timeless, cult classic, even if it had 10/10stars it would still be underrated. Love!
This is my all time favorite movie. The way that Johnny Depp plays Edward is beautiful. Every time I watch the movie it brings me so much joy.
This movie still terrifies me as much as it did as a child. Good movie for good chills and to watch something different.

^*^Minor Spoilers^*^ Edward Scissorhands (played by the outstanding Johnny Depp) tells the story of a young man with scissors for hands. Unable to hold or hug anyone, he still is able to love with a passion. This movie, directed by the genius Tim Burton, is a visual masterpiece. The sets are beautiful; I loved how they made the amazing contrast with the pastel houses and Edward's castle. One of the main things that completed the beauty of this movie was the amazing score by composer Danny Elfman. Winona Ryder plays Kim Boggs, the cheerleader who has Edward's affection. She excels in this role, and the chemistry between her and Edward create a tear-jerking performance ("Hold me"..."I can't"). Vincent Price delivers a great performance as the Inventor.  Overall, I give this movie ***** out of *****; a must rent for all Tim Burton fans!

This movie is very well done. But some flaws are very noticeable. For example:
1. The music is not very well proportioned.2. The blood can be seen to be fake.3. Villages are not realistic: I know that American villages are like villages in cartoons. The houses are all the same, and the interiors are very lightly decorated.This movie is pretty good overall.

reviews.review_title: An emotional fairytale of modern world. A must watch movie
reviews.content: An excellent movie. I started to watch it only because I saw Johnny Depp in the cast but the unique story of the film, the idea, theme and on top of all Jhonny Depp's acting, which we all expect from him, makes it top class. Edward (Johnny Dep) was abnormal in the way that his hands were actually scissors but he has imagination of an artist and he can make anything he want with those hands. He was brought to normal world by a kind local Avon lady, Pegg Bogs (Dianne Wiest). The so called normal world couldn't accept him despite his talents and efforts to please them and this makes him run away to where he came from. The end isn't that bad but not good either. I wish if the people could knew the truth about him and the reality about Jim and what ever happened with them, right from the start (i.e. robbery till murder). It was emotional. I was so happy to find out Edward didn't die in the end but I believe he deserved better. He was promised that a doctor can fix his hands and he can become normal. Would have been great if that promise was fulfilled.

reviews.review_title: ....I couldn't sleep after the movie...it kept me thinking
reviews.content: This is exactly the type of movies I want to make when I become a director. A movie about fantasies, drama and romance...I'll never ever forget this movie. It was the best movie ever made, in my opinion, and I call this movie an ideal movie and the Johnny Depp the ideal character creater.

this was one of the most beautiful films i ever seen. it's a well making drama and it as also a love tale of a man with scissors substituting his hands. it's a film very sad because it relates a impossible love of a deformed man with a beautiful lady. this is one of the films that you should see with all the family because is so beautiful that you will love it

Despite some people's comments, i feel that this film is one of the best ever made. It is a beautiful story, a modern fairytale, and definitely Burton's greatest work, if not Johnny Depp's. The cinematography is beautiful, the score is so haunting and Depp's performance as Edward absolutely melts my heart. I love how Burton can make even Suburbia seem sinister! He is a fabulous director and this just shows how good he can be. The story of the outsider looking in has been done a thousand times, it's true, but this film stands out as the best of these. I feel it also makes a statement about the close-mindedness of secular communities, unable to deal with a simple complication or development. It stuns me every time i watch it, and makes me fall back in love with the whole film. The fantasy genre has always been my favourite, and this film, is one of the best.Surely no-one with a heart can fail to be touched by the sheer chastity and innocence of such an incredible film. I will not hear a word against it!!!

I've always admired Tim Burton. He's an amazing director. This movie came out when I was four years old and I only saw it recently at film camp. As the opening credits came up, I started crying. It's that powerful of a movie. If you're not a Burton fan see this, because you will be by the end. The man is simply a genius. And, Planet of the Apes never happened, do you hear me?

I watched this movie for the first time last night and I was completely awestruck. I couldn't find words to describe what I had seen. This film is one of only four films which I have awarded a 10/10. Tim Burton's "Edward Scissorhands" is the most impressing and fascinating movie I have seen in several years. It blew me away.I am still kind of chocked. This film conveys so many emotions it's hard to explain. In one specific scene I didn't know whether to laugh, cry, be scared or be happy, so the result was something in between: I laughed and I was tearful, frightened and worried.I won't try to explain this movie. You should just see it - now! The less you know, the better your experience will be.A true piece of art.

reviews.review_title: there are two types of people...
reviews.content: There are two types of people who watch Edward Scissorhands... Those who are like Edward and those who are like the boyfriend who wants to beat up edward for enchanting "his woman".If you are the beautiful, creative, passionate (and alittle pale) type who relates to Edward... good on you! Please don't give up. There is a little artist in most of us, and most people have felt awkward and alienated at some point... this film will speak to you, cut to your heart and stay with you for life.Then there is the spiteful types who think that just because they dont relate to Edward's pain that the whole film is bad for others. Shame on you! One can't just write off a film with so much depth, and if it seems to you to be nothing else... but an imaculate visual feast in a fantasy like world... Perhaps you should go watch war and teen films about football heroes and cheerleaders, leaving the depth and spirit of this beautiful film to those with empathy and desire to be unique.If you are the third type of person who loves this film (the girl who ran away from an aching ed out there...) This is a tear jerker and a real eye opener.From the perspective of Edward himself, this film lets you feel alone, gifted and magical for a few hours. A great film to encourage tolerance of others who are different... and rather against those who just judge on face value.Loved it, bought it.... you should at least rent it... :)The musical score is beautiful Danny! Thanks again for helping Burton weave his magic audibly.

This movie is truly remarkable. It's a movie that in some way, reaches everyone that watches it.I could think of every glorifying word I know to describe this movie. But, in all truth, this movie is indescribable. This is Tim Burton at his best. In this movie you see the imagination of a child come to life in a beautiful tale. I think, that in a way, everyone secretly wants to know someone like Edward. Because, quite frankly, the one thing that really separates Edward from "normal" people is his actions and personality. Edward is gentle, he is kind to everyone he meets, he is polite and caring. Edward is something that is a fantasy just for those traits, never mind the fact that he has scissors for hands.I think thats what gives this movie the magic it has. The fact that, by the end of this movie you realize this fact. You watch the people in the town drive him away, and your sad. And, your not just sad because Edward is alone. Your not just sad that Edward doesn't have a family any more. Your sad at how the towns people acted. Your sad how it all came crashing down. And, finally, your sad at almost how real that situation is, and your disappointed because, in a way, you can see people you know, in your own town, doing the same thing...

reviews.review_title: The Number One best movie I have ever seen!
reviews.content:
Don't be turned off by the fantasy-like look of this amazing film. This has recently become my number one all time favorite movie. This movie captures the essence of innocence and cruelty. Although the main character in this movie (Edward Scissorhands) is a fantasy and people may get the impression of a character unable to relate this, it is not so. In fact, I have never cried harder during a movie.Tim Burton, the best director ever, (look for his other films) creates the perfect cast, setting, and plot in this movie. The soundtrack by Danny Elfman,(look for the soundtrack) creates the most beautiful music ever in a movie. You can hear the drama and comedy flowing through the music.
This is the most touching, sweetest, and the most beautiful fairy tale ever. This is a captivating tale of romance, comedy, and drama. Just think, a story of someone who loves and is so gentle on the inside, but has sharp knives on the outside. Of all the movies I have ever seen, I recommend this the most.

This movie brings the feeling just like when you are a litle boy. Remember when you watched Aladin en you wished you could be him, well this movie goes farther. This is a great drama and a teriffic appearence by johnny depp in this movie. He had to win an Oscar for this movie.

The score for this wonderfully orchestrated fantasy goes beyond words. The essence of the characterization of Edward is truly one of the great masterpieces of Tim Burton. The emotional depth of the Grand Finale Selection is without words. Truly, Burton's Finest.

reviews.review_title: Best Movie Ever -- see the movie before reading this
reviews.content: This is the movie where it all comes together--the most creative story, the most moving music, the immaculate direction, and the impeccable cast. "Edward Scissorhands" is art, perfected.  There has never been a story told so eloquently as done here by Tim Burton; this movie is the best thing in the world, not to overstate it.First of all, the whole movie is absolutely beautiful.  It's hard to pick one, but the shot of Peg looking in her car mirror is a wonderful example of the aesthetics Burton uses throughout the film, mixing bright color with a darkness that is crisp, and not gloomy.Danny Elfman's score for "Edward Scissorhands" is the best I've ever heard. It is touching, funny, and always appropriate.  Tim Burton makes the right move playing Elfman's music almost non-stop during the movie, and there isn't a false note throughout.Little needs to be said for the cast: phenomenal performances by Depp, Ryder, Wiest, Arkin, and Price pull this movie together.As for Kim...she knew that she and Edward could not be together as long as he was outcast.  She couldn't just sneak up there every day after school or something.  And as she said, she'd rather he remembered her the way she was. But the silver lining of the movie is, no matter how long Edward stays up there alone, he is happier than he would have been without his days with Kim.As for the blocks of ice...Edward lives in a house owned by an inventor who created a human being, plus all those cookies and God knows what else.  A big freezer somewhere is not far-fetched.This movie really is about being different, and the functionalism of society.  It goes over the top on purpose--with the house colors and plain lawns, and the shot with all the husbands backing out of their driveways to go to work all at once--to stress that this is just basic American suburbia. Edward changes the lawns, and in the end, when society's disturbed, the party responsible is rejected.Of course, there's always the more fun way of looking at it--that it's just a bunch of stuff that happened.  Do that.

reviews.review_title: The Perfect Holiday Movie - but forget the scissors, what about the teeth?
reviews.content: Holiday movie watching is not a tradition to be taken lightly. Non-binding clothing must be donned, a hot drink must be within arm's reach, and a cozy blanket must be tucked up against one's chin to foil any possibility of draught. In a perfect world, a fire would sizzle and pop in the fireplace, and inclement weather would rage against the window panes.And Johnny Depp would be on my couch. Or at least in my DVD player. "Edward Scissorhands" (1990) is a heartwarming, quirky romantic comedy with a twist of fantasy. It's the story of an awkward, innocent misfit, and it's just the right choice for a wintery evening in.My personal love affair with Johnny Depp began in 1990 when he played Edward Scissorhands. But I'm going to try to be objective in this review, really I am.It begins as a kind of fairy tale, a grandmother tucking a child into bed while explaining the mysterious origins of snow. I would like to say the film is suitable for the whole family, but there is one seductress scene where the neighborhood hussy (Marge, delightfully played by Kathy Baker) tries to Mrs. Robinsonize young Edward in the back room of her beauty parlor, the innuendo of which would bump the film into the PG-13 category. (Hooray!) Edward (Johnny Depp) is an awkward misfit boy, who has been created with scissory blades where his hands should be. He speaks only 169 words in the entire movie and looks at the world with wide wonder. He desperately wants to do the right thing; moving around gingerly so he doesn't stab or slash anything. By the time Edward punctures the water bed with an accidental poke, and then tries to fix the spouting water by covering it up with stuffed animals, he has won our hearts.Edward Scissorhands is regarded by many critics to be the crazy-haired director Tim Burton's finest film. No argument here. Burton calls it his favorite creation as well. It was his first project with the then 27-year-old Depp, the first of seven collaborations between the two.The Burton/Depp relationship itself bears some discussion.Why is there this unholy alliance between the disheveled, uncombed lunatic Tim Burton and the man-god Johnny Depp? What fuels this obsession of Johnny's to keep making Tim's movies? Johnny once said in an interview that he would do anything Tim Burton asked him to do. ANYTHING! (capitals mine) Yes, Johnny, we KNOW you love Tim but you don't have to say "yes" every time the man drinks too much tequila and has a weird movie idea.I have a theory about why Tim and Johnny are joined at the artistic hip: People with gaps in their front teeth are magnetically drawn to other people with gaps in their front teeth. Hear me out, there's empirical data.In orthodontic terms, this gap is called diastema, and I think the National Science Foundation needs to throw some serious research money at the diastema-to-love correlation. Tim Burton has it. Johnny has it. Johnny's life partner Vanessa Paradis has it - the exact same gap in her front teeth that Johnny has. Coincidence? My theory is that there is a glittery, invisible beam of attraction that emanates from the heart, comes up through the esophagus and is emitted out the gappy tunnel between the teeth. It then passes through the other person's gappy tunnel, and locks on to their heart, resulting in love. Or a movie deal.But Burton and Depp aren't the only ones involved here.If it is possible for me to love anyone in this film as much as I love Johnny Depp, it is Dianne Wiest. She superbly plays Peg, the Avon lady and the mom everyone wants to have. Her reaction upon first meeting the frightening looking Edward? "What happened to your hands? Where are your parents? I think you need to just come home with me." She adopts Edward and brings him home to live with her family. I want her to adopt me.This was Vincent Price's final film. Price plays a small but poignant role as Edward's creator/father, living in the eerie, Gothic castle, and kindly tutoring Edward in all subjects including proper decorum when tea is served. Ironically, Price's death scene was to be the last scene he ever filmed before his own death, a fitting farewell to the Crown Prince of all things mysterious.Winona Ryder plays Edward's love interest, Kim. Edward is instantly transfixed by her photograph, but the relationship never materializes. SPOILER ALERT: At the end of the film, Edward hears the words he has longed to hear from Kim: "Hold me." He tries, but cannot, because he is afraid of hurting her. But she maneuvers in past his blades and snuggles against his chest in what is possibly the sweetest embrace in all of cinematic history.In real life, Johnny and Winona had a hotly fueled affair that was to end in a bad breakup and a tattoo revision. I think it's obvious why things didn't work out: Winona has good teeth.** Special thanks to longtime friend Carlos Alcala, the "Chick Flick Guy," for prodding me to finally write this and for including this on his wonderful romantic comedy Blog!

This movie is about one of the best movies that you definately need in your movie collection. Depp and Ryder just act completely in harmony and grab you closer and closer into the film. I have to admit there were some parts in the movie that seemed rather odd, but all in all it was a fantastic movie. Hint, if you ever catch it on TV an don't have it already in your movie collection, TAPE IT!

reviews.review_title: I think it's a sad movie
reviews.content: I don't think Edward Scissorhands is a good film, the story is good, but the main characters in it are too thin. But I still like it, for Jonny Depp. He is the only one who can act as Edward. Edward is a sad character, so despair, even when Winora says she loves him. Do you see the sadness in his eyes?

Edward Scissorhands, directed by Tim Burton (Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and Planet of the Apes), is a movie with one very strong message. Throughout the movie it is shown that in most places there is not much room for acceptance. Tim Burton wrote in a passage after making this movie that the strongest impulse for the film was to show that from day one people categorise you. I believe that Tim Burton demonstrated this message very well in the movie. However, as much as I agree with the message in the movie, overall I didn't like the actual movie at all. For me in some places it was too dark and for a family movie the strong themes and messages in it could be confusing for children. I believe that maybe it could have been advertised to an older audience, rather than families. I also found this movie to be boring at some points, but that is only my opinion. Nevertheless you cannot deny that the acting in this movie is not to be commended for. Johnny Depp who plays Edward in the movie did a fine job at portraying his character, as did Winona Ryder, Dianne Wiest, Anthony Michael Hall and all of the other actors and actresses in this movie. Overall I would give this movie three stars, but only because of the creative way the message was expressed and the quality of the actors.

(Possible Spoilers)Rarely do we get the chance to see such a breathtaking vision of movie making. This film is so beautiful, from Tim's dark story telling and hidden depths to Johnny's wonderful and touching performance as the innocent and misunderstood Edward.It is one of those movies, which capture your imagination and stick within you for the rest of your time. We find Edward a lone, innocent man, accepted into a society where as hard as he tries he cannot fit in, only because of one thing, his hands, or lack of them. It follows a route many of us may have experienced some time in our lives, not being accepted because of something, and this I believe is what touches us the most about this movie. The way in which we can relate to the innocence and want of acceptance. It contains the essentials needed in the 'perfect' movie, comedy (see some of Edwards facial expressions), strong powerful emotions and even romance.It is a typical Tim Burton movie (Nightmare Before Christmas, Sleepy Hollow) deep and dark though with a touch of sensitivity, following his normal dark fairytale route flowing through strong emotions and the usual not so happy ending. reviews.review_title: One word defines this movie: Bittersweet.
reviews.content: I could say a lot of things about this movie: how it is a fun twist to the classic horror film (it event includes an interesting rendition of the peasants storming the castle), a revealing portrait about teen angst, and a bittersweet tragedy that makes you wish that "happily ever after" could be an option for Edward. It is a harsh critique of suburbia and American culture in general, one that I identitfied with very much in junior high school when this movie came out.I pulled this movie out and watched it again after four years and was surprised at how much more I got out of it this time through.  But I must admit that after all the analysis and subjective pandering, this movie really touches me on an emotional level.Johnny Depp is perfect as Edward. His mannerisms and portrayal of Edward's innocence are completely disarming. It is this innocence that makes the audience want the world to be innocent toward Edward in return.  But of course it isn't and, although Edward's hands are weapons, he has little to defend himself with.This is one of the best films of the 1990s, a comic/tragic fairy tale.

(I think Edward is a representation of someone with those traits, kinda like me...)
Interestingly the rest of my family (with the exception of my mother) didn't like this film because they didn't like how odd the setting of the village was and they didn't get why the characters seem to act so naively/ illogically. It wasn't until I pointed out that the film could be a representation of Edward's point of view that they began to understand my thoughts on the film.
Overall I think this film is superb and is definitely a good watch for someone with an op en mind.

reviews.review_title: A nice hark back and tale of whimsy

Edward Scissorhands isn't a film that fears showing the viewer a unique and otherworldly scenario and although a lot of the cinematographic techniques employed is antiquated and there could be CG trickery making scenes feel like more of a reality to the viewer, it's appreciable how limitations were utilized given the time of the film's release.Edward is a very soft-spoken and coy character; given his appearance one might anticipate a horror film but he's simply an inventor's muse made flesh. He's brought home from the mansion where he was stowed away in the attic for several years and all kinds of interesting antics ensue once he's returned home various forays and attempts at adapting to life in their quaint suburban neighborhood lead its denizens to appreciate Edward and his scissors for hands. I hope that synopsis can carry you over to an idea of what to expect if you're to watch.
Johnny Depp is my favorite actor and this performance shows something special. Overall the concept is quirky yet brilliant.

reviews.review_title: Subtext is the name of the game...
reviews.content: I couldn't disagree more with the "Frankenstein" analysis of this movie. (Aside - even the story of Frankenstein is not a "monster" story. It is a story about man's drive to create due to his inability to give birth.) Edward is a freak. Edward is exotic. Edward is to be stared at. In short - Edward is an artist. But, Edward is not a monster. You don't invite "monsters" to sleep in your daughters bed!I agree that this movie is full of subplot and symbolism. The central theme - as I see it - is "artists are misunderstood". But more than this, "artists are created in a vacuum - away from meddling 'ordinary folk'." I believe there are two kinds of artists - artists who identify themselves with the ordinary people of this world and artists who live completely inside their imaginary world. It is obvious Tim Burton would count himself as the latter type. All his movies have a definite feel of "manufactured sets". You never know if they take place in the past or the future. (I saw the movie tonight on the science fiction channel.)I agree Tim Burton is a master of his craft - even honour him with the title of "Artist". But after watching Edward Scissorhands - one walks away thinking that artists belong in a gothic mansion secluded from the "mob". I couldn't disagree more. The best-loved art - is art that makes a connection with the 'ordinary folk' of the world.Tim Burton does make one small acknowledgement to the 'ordinary folk'. In the movie, Edward has a hard time feeding himself. When he goes to the BBQ in his honour, he is fed by the guests of the party. But at one point, Edward is even in danger of becoming the main course. Have no fear Tim - if anyone is going to eat you up and spit you out, it is Hollywood. But I am sure you know this.I should mention - I am not an artist. Just an ordinary working-class person.One final comment - this is not a love or hate type of movie. It is a movie to be watched and analysed. It is food for your eyes and your mind. Open your eyes and keep a critical mind.

In a movie that could only be created by the morbid-but-sentimental mind of Tim Burton, Johnny Depp has one of his first major roles as a needy, gentle-spirited invention-gone-wrong. The movie takes place in a strange Technicolor town of bright houses, square lawns, and a looming mad scientist's castle at the top of the hill. When Diane West, playing an exquisitely sensitive and maternal Avon lady, decides to visit the castle, she finds a boy named Edward living there all alone. Edward is not a normal person, just as you'd expect from Tim Burton: he's a leatherclad, melancholy freak of nature with foot-long scissors in place of fingers. Overcoming her initial fear, Diane West takes pity on the childlike Edward, and invites him into her home. The ensuing story is somewhat typical of all the "fish-out-of-water" stories ever told - Edward is at first accepted with open arms by the neighborhood, and takes part in hedge-clipping and haircuts, as well as becoming something of a local celebrity. To make matters more complicated, Edward innocently falls in love with the Avon lady's daughter, a waifish little beauty played with the perfect blend of teenage passion and innocence by Winona Ryder.But a few misunderstandings and dangerous missteps lead the townspeople to reject Edward, leaving you worrying for Edward Scissorhands to the very end of the film. The movie is awash with cartoon-like settings, bizarre characters, and a wistful score by Danny Elfman. Johnny Depp excels as the gentle monster who can never be completely understood by the humans he encounters ... anyone who can make you like them in spite of having enormous blades for hands is a true sweetheart. This is a melancholy, bittersweet bit of Tim Burton cinema magic at is best. Not to be missed.

This movie is to Tim Burton what "Pulp Fiction" was to Tarantino, and "Taxi Driver" to Scorsese.  A definitive directorial vision, put artfully and beautifully on film.  The story, apparently, is a metaphorical reflection of the lonely childhoods of both Burton and screenwriter Caroline Thompson.  The role of Edward put Johnny Depp on the Hollywood map as an artist to be considered for roles of depth and substance.  Burton's direction is flawless, oddly moving, and visually stunning, with the same eerie and head-tilting weirdness that audiences have come to expect from his material.  Long time collaborator Danny Elfman provides a score that ranks among his very best.  The socio-political observations, citations, and commentary that the story and movie provide are both on the ball and thought provoking.  As a character, Edward's tragic innocence, awesome talent, and extraordinary imagination are brought to life with remarkable sensitivity by Depp.  Winona Ryder, Alan Archan, Diane Weist, and Anthony Michael Hall are wonderful in their respective supporting roles. A film that will be remembered.  10/10.

reviews.review_title: Edward is an unfinished invention that comes to life. He is brought into society and then forced to leave due to his inability to be accepted into society
reviews.content: Edward Scissorhands was about a man made by a scientist. The scientist dies before he is able to give Edward (Johnny Depp) real hands instead of scissor hands. He is later picked up by Pegg (Diane Wiest) and brought into town to live with her and her family. Edward has a tough time adjusting to normal life, but ends up charming almost everyone. His love for Pegg's daughter, Kim (Wynona Ryder) does him in. Her jealous boyfriend, Jim (Anthony Michael Hall), makes Edward out to be a monster and finally banishes Edward back to his mansion to live in isolation.The theme of the movie was about isolation. Once Edward's inventor died he did not understand it or know what to do because he was just brought into the world. So, there he was all alone in the dark and dreary mansion isolated from society until Pegg discovers him and brings him into her world. Edward is misunderstood by Pegg's neighbors and they further isolate him by keeping their distance at first and gossiping with one another when he first arrives in the neighborhood. Once everybody discovers he has a talent for sculpting and haircutting, he becomes popular in that little community. Edward gets pushed into the spotlight once everyone gets over their fear and become interested in his cutting abilities. This act again isolates him because he becomes "special". Edward just wants to fit in and be like everyone else instead of a showpiece. Once Jim starts to see that Edward has feelings for Kim, he becomes very jealous. He makes Edward out to be a thief. This also isolates Edward from his community because they all start to fear him again. They do not agree with what he is doing so they turn their backs on him. Edward then isolates himself for good by going back to the mansion at the end of the movie.Another film, Frankenstein, reminds me of Edward Scissorhands. Frankenstein was also a scientist's invention that came to life. Frankenstein was also misunderstood and people were frightened of him because he was different. People chose to isolate themselves from Frankenstein out of fear of the unknown. Frankenstein, like Edward did not choose to live and be targeted by people for being different and not fitting into the cookie-cutter version of society.One technique in Edward Scissorhands that was used was the lighting. When Pegg goes into the mansion it is made to look dark and ominous by just having sunlight shine through the windows. It gave a look of abandonment since it was the middle of the day and it was pitch-black in the mansion. Another technique was the display of motifs. One motif was Edward's mansion. The mansion symbolized Edward and his isolation from society. The mansion was big, black and creepy looking and isolated from the other bright and cheery houses on the block. The people in the neighborhood were also a motif. They were meant to portray society and how they treat people that do not look or act like them. People like Edward feel isolated because society does not want to accept that not everybody is like them.

Edward Scissorhands is a tragic fairytale, telling the story of a love that could never be and showing what happens when two very different worlds collide. Written and directed by Tim Burton (Big Fish, Sleepy Hollow), the plot of Edward Scissorhands all starts when Avon lady Peg Boggs, played by Dianne Wiest (Practical Magic, Footloose), desperate for a sale, ventures into a dark, scary castle, where she meets one of the late owner's creations; a man named Edward and played by Johnny Depp (Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl, Secret Window). However, during his creation, the elderly Inventor died and so Edward was never finished and, instead of hands, has knives and scissor blades. Wiest's character, being kind at heart, decided to take him home with her to her house in the cheery world of suburbia. From the moment he arrives, Edward has problems fitting in, but he soon finds that he has a talent that endears him to the community. All seems to be going well, even the fact that Edward develops a crush on Peg's daughter Kim, played by Winona Ryder (Mr. Deeds, Little Women).Edward Scissorhands marks the beginning of a long, successful partnership between Tim Burton and Johnny Depp - the director and actor went on to work on another three films together, Ed Wood, Sleepy Hollow and the soon-to-be-released Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. These films, with the possible exception of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory share Burton's trademark subtle humour and dark, occasionally scary moments; for example, in Edward Scissorhands, the scene where we first see Edward; emerging from the shadows; dressed completely in black and with what little light there was, glinting off of his blades. He is immediately portrayed as a character to be slightly wary of. As the film goes on, we see that he doesn't mean to be violent; he can't help who he is.The film is a modern take on the time-old story of Beauty and the Beast - Kim is the popular, beautiful girl; with the brawny, trouble-making boyfriend. Edward is the anti-social, abnormal 'beast' character - feared by the 'normal' people. The only difference between the fairy tale and Edward Scissorhands is the ending.Overall - the film successfully tells the tale of the collision of two cultures; showing the innocent side of a character who in many ways could be seen as dangerous. It shows a doomed relationship, struggling against everything and, ultimately, leaving us, the audience, with a glimmer of hope.It has very few bad points, apart from being slightly too light-hearted occasionally - for example, the hair cut scenes are verging on silly, however, I would recommend this film to anyone who likes films that don't necessarily follow mainstream cinema.

Tim Burton's small masterpiece follows the story of an outsider thrown into a civilisation where everything is precise and everyone is stiff. Johnny Depp stars as the title character, a man - made boy whose inventor father dies before he could replace Edward's scissor hands with human hands. Living alone in an old mansion, the local Avon lady visits and takes Edward under her wing, introducing him into a society through his topiary and hairdressing skills. There, Edward learns that the power of love in some people can overcome physical appearances, while in others; it merely causes fear and anger.Depp's performance is, in one word, extraordinary. Even with very few lines, he has this incredible ability to be as physically expressive as silent stars; he is (I believe) one of very few actors who can achieve this expertise today. Always a very attentive performer, Depp creates an Edward that is rigid, self - conscious, and apprehensive in many ways. The various emotions that play across his face throughout the film is why Depp is, or if not should be, classed as one of our best character actors in the 2Oth Century. From the first moment I saw Edward, I immediately felt sorry for him. Subject to his facial expressions and the way he talks and acts around the unusual surroundings he encounters, Depp's character is almost like a little child lost in a world he has never known before, which he portrays brilliantly.Burton's creation of fantasy films seems to come naturally to him, which is why this film works so well and shows off his outstanding talent and imagination. How he manages to create a world that is so intristic, yet to the audience it doesn't seem legitimate, amazes me. He dreams up a town that is so pastel and like everyone living in that town is stuck in this bubble, which in some way Edward seems to pop that bubble and open the residents to see the real world. No other director could make a film that contains that mix of fantasy added with humour and drama and actually make it work more than Burton.The use or eerie music helps to establish each scene as individual and unique. Created by Danny Elfman, each piece of score identifies with the characters, more so with Edward, as when he creates his topiary; the fast score fits perfectly with the scene. In some way it displays Edward's concentration and talent while producing his "art" to its full extent.For me, the best part of this movie is just how Burton combines the different genres used: horror, fantasy, romance, drama and comedy. His capability to do this blows me way and added with Depp's truly stunning performance, this film makes me want to watch it over and over again.

Early in his career, director Tim Burton finally matched his visual creativeness with a sense of restraint with the remarkable Edward Scissorhands.  Created by a Frankenstein-like inventor (Vincent Price) in a castle overlooking a quaint American town, Edward (Johnny Depp) is a young man bereft of both social skills and hands, which have been replaced by a scissor-like contraption.  When rescued from the mansion and escorted into town by the local Avon lady (Dianne Wiest), after initially being accepted by the locals, soon finds himself in peril as the result of not being able to conform.  The movie, a story of acceptance and assimilation, works on the strength of the performances, a gorgeous color palette, a great score by Danny Elfman, and some impressive cinematography.  Edward Scissorhands, arguable Burton's best film, is as great today as it was when it was initially released.

A film that only Burton could make, his direction is as sound as usual and he manages to evoke considerableFrom the wild and wacky mind of Tim Burton comes Edward Scissorhands, a tragic and charming look at a man with scissors for hands. A film that only Burton could make, his direction is as sound as usual and he manages to evoke considerable sympathy for this tragic figure who is, otherwise, a normal man but cursed to live his days with scissors as hands. Johnny Depp does a great job bringing this man to life and brings a certain tenderness and has fantastic chemistry with Winona Ryder when it comes to the romantic element of the film. The writing is incredibly strong and, together with Burton's direction, keeps this one reined in and keeps it from getting out of control when it easily could have with such a crazy premise. The characters are well developed and truly multi-dimensional. Edward Scissorhands' portrayal of suburban life also feels delightfully and quintessentially late 80s, early 90s and really serves as a perfect backdrop for the introduction of such a weird and unique person. Though I may be one of the few to have never seen Edward Scissorhands, it is truly timeless and will live on for a long, long time due to its fairy tale and thematic elements that really are universal and its ability to be both unique, yet incredibly stirring, tragic, and moving. This one is Tim Burton at his very finest.

The script, while not the strongest category of the film, was still very touching, and added to the charm and suspense that was already ensured in the film. The direction by Tim Burton had all his trademarks, very dark and suspenseful, evident in films like Batman and Sleepy Hollow, if a little odd at times, which is fairly typical of Burton. Tim Burton doesn’t have the staying power with me that he once did. When I think of modern Burton I tend to think of very drab, heavily CG’d, washed out looking films that tend to oversell on the “dark and whimsical” style that he was once aTim Burton doesn’t have the staying power with me that he once did. When I think of modern Burton I tend to think of very drab, heavily CG’d, washed out looking films that tend to oversell on the “dark and whimsical” style that he was once a pioneer of. It’s such a shame that I dread seeing any new movie of his because I know, deep down, that he still has the potential of creating great, fantastical films. When I think of Tim Burton, I think fondly of the days of Batman ’89, Beetlejuice, Ed Wood and, most personally, Edward Scissorhands. It’s a film I grew up watching as a kid on my mom’s laserdisc. I was intrigued by the look of the film, the music, and Edward himself. It had been many years since I have seen this movie to completion, and as an adult I have been able to gain a newfound appreciation for it. The story follows the titular Edward Scissorhands, a lonely, incomplete creation of a professor (played by Vincent Price) who is discovered by local suburban saleswoman Peg Boggs. Feeling sympathy for Edward, she takes him back to her home in a suburban neighborhood filled with incredibly nosey housewives that are smitten by this mysterious person. Edward quickly finds a place for himself, creating hedge art for the people and even as their hair stylist. Edward also falls for Peg’s daughter Kim, who is uncertain of Edward at first but slowly starts to care for him. The whole movie plays out like a gothic fairytale (it helps that the story is being told as a bedtime story), and the movie positively drips with Burton’s signature style. Edward’s intimidating presence heavily contrasts with the uniform, pastel-colored suburban neighborhood. He epitomizes the types of characters Burton tends to gravitate towards: the misunderstood misfit that may look strange, but is a gentle soul. Danny Elfman’s fantastic score helps to sell the film’s gothic fairytale feel, perfectly encapsulating Edward’s mood and state of mind in any given situation. The suburban neighbors are appropriately nosey, immediately infatuated with Edward but just as quickly are able to turn on him the second he makes a mistake. This would be the first of many collaborations between Burton and Johnny Depp, and this was a damn strong start. Depp is great in this film, perfectly capturing the innocence and awkwardness that Edward displays. Winona Ryder is great as Kim, and I even liked Anthony Michael Hall as Kim’s dirt bag boyfriend Jim. Everyone in the film is great, for that matter, even Vincent Price for as little screen-time as he gets portrays the same level of kindness that Edward carries over. Of course, I can’t forget to mention Stan Winston’s fantastic make-up and scissor effects for Depp. Edward’s look has become iconic and still unique among the rest of Burton’s catalogue. There only a few gripes I have with the film, like people for some reason not immediately helping him with basic tasks that he obviously can’t do with scissor hands. It’s usually played up for comedic affect but the entire time I couldn’t help but say, “Help him already!” These gripes are minor in the grand scheme of things, though. As far as discussing Tim Burton’s filmography is concerned, this easily in the top 5 in my opinion. Everything you need to know about him is on display in Edward Scissorhands. After all these years, I still think this movie is wonderful and it absolutely comes recommended not just for fans of Tim Burton, but just for being a good, well-rounded movie.

rt_summary: A scientist (Vincent Price) builds an animated human being -- the gentle Edward (Johnny Depp). The scientist dies before he can finish assembling Edward, though, leaving the young man with a freakish appearance accentuated by the scissor blades he has instead of hands. Loving suburban saleswoman Peg (Dianne Wiest) discovers Edward and takes him home, where he falls for Peg's teen daughter (Winona Ryder). However, despite his kindness and artistic talent, Edward's hands make him an outcast.
meta_summary: In this modern fairy tale, Edward is a gentle, naive creation with razor sharp scissors for hands. When he is taken home by a kindly Avon lady live with her family, his adventure in the pastel paradise of Suburbia begins! (20th Century Fox)
